qas.question: Which Lophotrochozoa phyla have similar egg development?
How do the cells of Lophotrochozoa eggs arrange themselves?

answers.text: after the 4-cell stage, descendants of these 4 cells form a spiral pattern

qas.question: What is the Lophotrochozoa spiral egg-cell pattern sometimes called?
Which Lophotrochozoa phyla have no egg development?

plausible_answers.text: after the 4-cell stage, descendants of these 4 cells form a spiral pattern

qas.question: How do the cells of Lophotrochozoa eggs destroy themselves?
What is the Lophotrochozoa spiral egg-cell pattern required to be called?
What phyla is no longer able to make eggs?

context: The "Lophotrochozoa" hypothesis is also supported by the fact that many phyla within this group, including <a0_0><b3_0><b6_0>annelids<b6_0/>, <b7_0>molluscs<b7_0/>, nemerteans and flatworms<b3_0/><a0_0/>, follow a similar pattern in the fertilized egg's development. When their cells divide <a1_0><b4_0>after the 4-cell stage, descendants of these 4 cells form a spiral pattern<b4_0/><a1_0/>. In these phyla the "fates" of the embryo's cells, in other words the roles their descendants will play in the adult animal, are the same and can be predicted from a very early stage. Hence this development pattern is often described as "<a2_0><b5_0>spiral determinate cleavage<b5_0/><a2_0/>".
